#Text=Ramallah

#Text=Ramallah ( Arabic رام الله Rāmallāh ) is a small city ( population , approximately 57,000 ) in the Palestinian Territories , located within the West Bank region , some 15 km ( 10 miles ) north of Jerusalem .
#Text=Since the inception of the Palestinian National Authority , Ramallah has acted as the de facto capital city of the Palestinian administration .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Modern Ramallah was founded in the mid-16th century by the Haddadins , a Jordanian tribe of brothers descended from Ghassanid Christian Arabs .
#Text=The Haddadins , led by Rashid Haddadin , arrived from east of the Jordan River near the Jordanian town of Shoubak .
#Text=The Haddadin migration is attributed to fighting and unrest among clans in that area .

#Text=According to modern living descendents of original Haddadin family members , Rahid 's brother Sabra Haddadin was hosting Emir Ibn Kaysoom , head of a powerful Muslim clan in the region , when Sabra 's wife gave birth to a baby girl .
#Text=According to custom , the Emir proposed a betrothal to his own young son when they came of age .
#Text=Sabra believed the proposal was in jest , as Muslim-Christian marriages were not customary , and gave his word .
#Text=When the Emir later came to the Haddadins and demanded that they fulfill their promise , they refused .
#Text=This set off bloody conflict between the two families .
#Text=The Haddadins fled west and settled on the hilltops of Ramallah , where only a few Muslim families lived at the time .
#Text=Today although town has a Muslim majority , Ramallah retains it 's title as a historically Christian Palestinian town
#Text=Ramallah is known for its religiously relaxed atmosphere — alcohol flows freely and movie theaters are well attended — and the cafes along its main streets .
#Text=Ramallah is , without question , the cultural capital of the West Bank , with a highly educated and fashionable population .

#Text=It is also the hub of Palestinian feminist activity ; the city ’s women frequently attend university rather than marry early , and several cafes run exclusively by women are used to fund local feminist organizations .
#Text=While there , it is easy to make small talk with the locals .
#Text=Unless you are firmly anti-Israeli occupation , it is advisable that you do more listening than actual talking yourself , however .
#Text=For the most part , Palestinians are glad to share their problems and plight to any western visitors .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Tourists with passports outside the Middle East have no problem entering or exiting Ramallah .
#Text=Make sure to have your passport and visa stamp with you .
#Text=Even though you will probably not need your passport to enter , you will be required to show your passport and stamp in order to re-enter Israel .
#Text=Once through the checkpoint , it is a short drive to downtown Ramallah .
#Text=Bear in mind that it is illegal for Israelis to enter Ramallah , under Israeli law .
#Text=On the way back , if you have an Israeli visa stamp or visa paper with your passport from when you arrived in Israel , then just stay on the bus as it arrives at Kalandia .
#Text=( Many passengers will get off here to go through a different security check . )
#Text=A couple of border guards with huge guns will come on to the bus to check passenger ID documents .
#Text=They will probably speak English well and may ask some questions about where you are from ( even though they can read it on your passport ) .
#Text=By bus
#Text=There is on Al-Nahder St. that serves buses from/to Nablus , and probably other destinations north .
#Text=There are at least three other bus stations in the city which also serve various destinations .
#Text=Nevertheless , they are all pretty close to each other .
#Text=From Jerusalem
#Text=the best connection to Ramallah is bus/sherut/serves 218 ( and sometimes 219 ) .

#Text=It departs from the Nablus Road station close to Damascus Gate on Nablus Rd ( aka Derech Shchem ) and will take you all the way to before mentioned bus station near the central square of al-Manara .
#Text=The price is ₪10-20 , and it takes around 45 minutes .
#Text=From Bethlehem
#Text=take a shared taxi ( Sherut/serviis ) from the Bethlehem bus station at Manger St. in the center .
#Text=The trip takes 45 min all the way around Jerusalem and costs ₪20 .
#Text=From Jericho
#Text=take a shared taxi ( Sherut/serviis ) from the central roundabout with the garden in the middle .
#Text=The taxis are waiting on the western side of the roundabout .
#Text=To increase your " luck " , you can also wait at the roundabout out of the city with the mosque .
#Text=Even hitchhiking from there makes sense .
#Text=The trip to Ramallah takes less than an hour for less than ₪15 .
#Text=The exact price is listed in the tourist information on the central roundabout in Jericho centre .
#Text=From Nablus
#Text=the trip is ₪10.5 and it takes about an hour .
#Text=Ask around
#Text=from which bus station in Nablus the correct ( big ) bus starts .
#Text=It is worth asking the drivers before you get on to double-check the bus is going to the right destination .
#Text=You might be surprised how many of them can speak basic English .
#Text=There are two main types of buses .
#Text=There are small ones with about 20 seats , and biggers ones that look more like coaches and are much more comfortable .
#Text=They all cost the same , and there is usually a rush of passengers pushing their way onto the buses .
#Text=By taxi
#Text=From Jerusalem 's Damascus Gate you can find taxis to Ramallah for approximately ₪80-100 depending on your bargaining skills .
#Text=You can also take a taxi to Kalandia checkpoint and walk through , picking up another taxi on the other side .
#Text=It costs about ₪30 from Kalandia to Ramallah centre .
#Text=By car
#Text=Heading north from Jerusalem on road #60 , you will arrive to Ramallah very quickly .
#Text=You will have to pass one Israeli checkpoint on the way : Kalandia .
#Text=By plane

#Text=There is no airport with scheduled passenger flights in the West Bank , so the only nearby passenger airports are Ben Gurion Airport in Lod , then heading towards Jerusalem or Queen Alia in Amman then heading towards Allenby Bridge aka King Hussein Bridge and passing through it - Visa on arrival for Israel is available for most common nationalities .
#Text=Ovda Airport near Eilat also sees international flights , but the connection from there to Ramallah is not all that straightforward and more time-consuming .
